ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained an elementary level of competence in classical literature (plus Dante) and learned how to close read well.
I learned how to place text in their respective times and what to get out of them relative to other pieces. It was extremely insightful.
Verbal and written communication, quick thinking, and logical reasoning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The syllabus of this course, while overwhelming, is amazing. I would say that lectures need to focus more on establishing an intellectual context and framework rather than focusing so intently on particulars.
Usual DS complaint that its too many works and too little time, but beside that the course was very well made. Maybe a little more text between the Bible and inferno, since that is some 1200 years.

The course encouraged students to consider the relevance of the studied texts in both an ancient and modern context. Students were able to draw connections between the ideologies of different societies and time periods by delving into the nature of the texts. The course also prompted original thinking and logical reasoning in order to identify the innumerable noteworthy features of the works.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was just a seminar so it worked fine.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would. The attention to detail and to tradition is great, and students are incredibly free to find their way into the texts however they can, as long as they can support and articulate their reading.
Yes. Its knowledge everyone should know. Well taught, well formatted.

I would highly recommend this course. The discussions revealed many intricacies within the texts while also considering their broader political and social relevance for each time period. Students learned to effectively articulate their thoughts on these matters through both verbal and written communication.
